title: Requires clinical education in pain management and establishes an advisory committee on pain management education
summary: Requires clinical education in pain management; requires every physician, physician assistant and specialist assistant practicing in the state to complete course work and training regarding pain management every four years; further establishes an advisory committee on pain management education.

BILL NUMBER:S2723

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public health law and the education law, in relation to
clinical education in pain management

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
The bill requires that all health care practitioners complete course
work or training regarding pain management. It creates an advisory
committee comprised of 12 members appointed by the commissioner of
health and the commissioner of education to help the Department of
Health develop, review and implement the appropriate educational
standards.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Section one of the bill creates a new article in the Public Health Law
to be Article 28-F titled "Pain Management" containing two sections
2900 and 2900-a. Section 2900 requires that all physicians, physician
assistants, and specialist assistants complete course work for
training in pain management every four years. It also creates an
exemption from this requirement for those practitioners who can
demonstrate that this requirement is not necessary. Section 2900-a
establishes an advisory committee on pain management, which will
consult with the commissioners of health and education for the
development, review, and implementation of the educational standards
required by the bill. Section four of the bill 6505-d amends the
education law to require clinical education in pain management for
licensed or certified health care practitioners under title eight of
the education law. Exemptions are again obtainable, as under the
Public Health Law.

JUSTIFICATION:
Many patients suffer needlessly from debilitating pain, caused by the
inadequate treatment of pain. Many health care professionals are
unaware of the resources available to their patients to relieve
chronic and acute pain. Some are unwilling to use those resources
because they fear that they will be wrongly subjected to prosecution
or professional discipline. This bill will ensure that health care
practitioners stay current on pain management techniques.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2010 - REFERRED TO HEALTH

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
To be determined.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act takes effect immediately.
